project_settings.name: webinos
project_settings.background:
Increasingly, users are owning more connected devices and expecting applications to keep preferences and status information synchronised across devices in different domains. The purpose of the webinos project is to define and deliver an open source platform, which will enable web applications and services to be used and shared consistently and securely over a broad spectrum of connected devices. To achieve this, it defines and provides an architecture and infrastructure to allow applications to run not only on a single device, but also across devices and domains. This applies to device features as well. New APIs are also provided to allow access to local and remote device resources and network resources in the Cloud.
webinos is a cross-domain platform for secure web application delivery. These domains include mobile, PCs, home media (TVs), and in-car units devices. It is specified as middleware installed on a selection of operating systems (OSs) on current devices to enable the consistent and secure web application user experience. At the time of writing the supported OSs and device platforms include: Android 2.3.x tested with devices: Nexus S, Asus Transformer Prime, Samsung Galaxy S2, Sonyericsson Xperia Arc, Galaxy Note Microsoft Windows 7 SP, Windows 7, Windows XP tested with laptops: Vaio z11, Dell, Asus EeePC (1215N) Linux: Ubuntu 10.04 LTS, Slackware 13.1, 13.37, Mint, Fedora tested with devices: VMWare Player, Samsung, Asus EeePC (1215N) TV variants of Cocom Churchill 177, Acer Revo etc. vehicle variant of Pandaboard Rev. A3 with Ubuntu 11.10 Mac OS X The webinos platform includes not only a set of newly defined APIs to enhance current web application runtime environments, but also an overlay network architecture to enable the webinos specific features.
project_settings.strategic_goals:
Promoting a “single service for every device” vision, webinos will move the existing baseline of web development from installed applications to services, running consistently across a wide range of connected devices, ensuring that the technologies for describing, negotiating, securing, utilizing device functionalities and adapting to context are fit for purpose.
Innovations in contextual description will be broad covering but not limited to device capabilities, network access, user identity and preferences, location, behaviourally induced properties and finally the more complex issue of the users’ social network context and social media engagement.
webinos will boost the industry migration towards web-based services. webinos can back this by providing inter-operable, standardised, open source technology utilizable across domains with direct commercially exploitable value. webinos will also act as an industry catalyst to encourage collaboration and discourage fragmentation in this space. There are strong industry moves towards Internet friendly and Internet integrated offerings, and there exists a window of opportunity to place the webinos technology on a robust open foundation that will remove economic barriers to engagement, embody policy on data privacy in concrete technology and creating a centre of web centric expertise.
project_settings.scope: Specification and architectural design of identity, discovery, notifications and messaging, policy and security, negotiation and compatibility, lifecycle, device and service capabilities, and state management and transfer functionality and software components.

entry.name: Application installation
entry.definition: Installation (or setup) of a program (including drivers, plugins, etc.) is the act of putting the program onto a computer system so that it can be executed. Because the requisite process varies for each program and each computer, many programs (including operating systems) come with a general-purpose or dedicated installer – a specialized program which automates most of the work required for their installation.

entry.name: Application lifecycle
entry.definition: A continuous process of managing the life of an application through governance, development and maintenance.

entry.name: Application Programming Interface (API)
entry.definition: An interface, i.e. a point of interaction between components, implemented by a software program that enables it to interact with other software. It facilitates interaction between different software programs similar to the way the user interface facilitates interaction between humans and computers.

entry.name: Applications
entry.definition: A complete, self-contained program that performs a specific function directly for the user. This is in contrast to system software such as the operating system kernel, server processes, libraries which exists to support application programs and utility programs.

entry.name: Authentication
entry.definition: Authentication is the process of confirming the correctness of the claimed identity.

entry.name: Certificate Authority (CA)
entry.definition: (i) A trusted third party 'clearing house' that issues digital signatures and digital certificates [ISO/IEC 27002:2005]. (ii) An infrastructure that issues certificates signed by or chained to a root certificate owned by the organization operating the CA infrastructure. CA-operating organizations typically own multiple root certificates, and apply various certification practices, e.g. level of business or domain validation required for issuing certificates signed by a particular root certificate. [Source: WAC]

entry.name: Child application
entry.definition: A child application is a self contained application package that is included within another application package (parent application). The are used as means for distributed application development and deployment where a parent application can export child applications to other devices in order to provide a service that can be distributed over several devices to the user.

entry.name: Cloud
entry.definition: Cloud computing is Web-based processing, whereby shared resources, software, and information are provided to computers and other devices (such as smartphones) on demand over the Internet. The Cloud can therefore refer to a range of services provided by remote infrastructures. A single instance of a Cloud is Amazon EC2, for example.

entry.name: Content adaptation
entry.definition: Is the action of transforming content to adapt to device capabilities. Content adaptation is usually related to mobile devices that require special handling because of their limited computational power, small screen size and constrained keyboard functionality.

entry.name: Context
entry.definition: Schilit et al. (1994) define context as where you are, who you are with, and what resources are nearby. This might suggest that context is more focused on the user’s surrounding as opposed to his/her inner states. A more specific definition is provided by Dey et al(2001). They defined it as any information that can be used to characterize the situation of an entity. An entity is a person, place, or object that is considered relevant to the interaction between a user and an application, including the user and applications themselves. Some examples of context types according to the actor/entity that is involved are: User context (contexts describing a user’s situation), software context (context describing a software’s situation). Context is more or less the set of facts or circumstances that surround a situation or event.

entry.name: Credential
entry.definition: Data that is transferred or presented to establish either a claimed identity or the authorizations of a system entity. [RFC 2828]

entry.name: Cross-Device Application
entry.definition: A webinos application capable of running on multiple devices, such as a set-top box and smartphone, not necessarily simultaneously.

entry.name: Device
entry.definition: A piece of hardware such as a mobile telephone, laptop, PC, home media centre, in-car system, netbook, tablet, game console, or router. The term “terminal” may be used analogue.

entry.name: Digital Certificate
entry.definition: A structure that associates an identity with an entity such as a user, a product or an Application Instance where the certificate has an associated asymmetric key pair which can be used to authenticate that the entity does, indeed, possess the Private Key. [IEC 62541-2, ed. 1.0 (2010-02)]

entry.name: Digital Signature
entry.definition: The result of a cryptographic transformation of data which, when properly implemented, provides the services of: (i) origin authentication, (ii) data integrity, (iii) signer non-repudiation. [FIPS 140-2]

entry.name: Event
entry.definition: A set of structured data that is meant to be exchanged among two or more addressable entities (e.g., applications, services).

entry.name: Feature
entry.definition: An option or functional capability available to the user.

entry.name: Node
entry.definition: Most commonly, 'Node' or 'nodejs' is used to refer to the NodeJS software which is used by webinos as a programming language and framework. From the website (NODE): "Node.js is a platform built on Chrome's JavaScript runtime for easily building fast, scalable network applications. Node.js uses an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model that makes it lightweight and efficient, perfect for data-intensive real-time applications that run across distributed devices."

entry.name: Personal Zone
entry.definition: This provides the means for users to manage their personal devices and services. The zone is exposed on each device as a set of local APIs, with a shared model of context that is synchronized across all devices in the zone together with the personal zone hub. The personal zone supports a single sign on mechanism so that users authenticate to a device, the device to the zone, and the zone to applications/services. The zone further supports an overlay networking model that hides the details of addressing and interconnect technologies. This is based upon 3rd party components that enable the zone to scale in the face on a continuing evolution of networking technologies. Note that some devices (e.g. a TV or networked printer) may be shared by several people, and forms part of a shared zone.

entry.name: Platform
entry.definition:
An operating system and software environment running on top of a device, managing the device hardware and providing common services for efficient execution of various application software.
Examples: The most common operating systems used in mobile smart phones include Symbian OS, Android, iOS, RIM Black Berry OS, or Windows Mobile. Popular modern operating systems for personal computers include Microsoft Windows, Mac OS X, and GNU/Linux. MeeGo is a Linux-based open source mobile operating system project, primarily targeted at mobile devices and information appliances in the consumer electronics market.

entry.name: Service
entry.definition: An addressable logical functional entity that is exposed on a device or a server. The service availability varies over time depending on the device status (on/off), service status (stopped/running/installed/uninstalled) and connection status (connected/disconnected). Examples of services are: an API to get the temperature from a sensor, a web API provided by a Web Server or a remote control API provided by a TV.

entry.name: WAC
entry.definition: The Wholesale Applications Community (WAC) is an open global alliance formed from the world’s leading telecoms operators. It has been established to increase the overall market for mobile applications. It strives to unite a fragmented applications marketplace by providing common developer tools, a revenue share model across the entire ecosystem and common network and terminal APIs.

entry.name: Widget
entry.definition: An interactive application for displaying and/or updating local data or data on the Web, packaged in a way to allow a single download and installation on a user's machine or mobile device. [WAC]

entry.name: Widget Renderer
entry.definition: Widget Renderers are the GUI element on each device capable of displaying a widget. We differentiate a renderer from a processor as the renderer only shows the widget and supports user interaction, whereas the processor unpacks the widget and manages installation. A widget renderer may be a stand-alone application, such as a browser, or may be a webinos-defined component. It is up to the implementation to actually differentiate between these concepts.

role.name: Application
role.description: Applications and services using webinos APIs.

role.name: User
role.description:
User of webinos apps.
* Of a webinos application. * Discovers availability of application. * Selects application for use and installation (including pre-conditional commercial steps) * Configures application for his personal preferences * Uses application to perform intended actions. * Shares knowledge about application availability with other users (e.g. invite/encourage to install)

role.name: Developer of webinos Apps
role.description: * Creates software packages * Develops application programs using various programming languages and toolkits (DIE,SDK, etc).

role.name: Developer of webinos Platform
role.description: * Creates functional specification and reference implementation of the webinos Platform. * Provides developer community support where application developers are engaged (e.g. the webinos project team).

role.name: Application Service Provider of installable webinos Application
role.description: * Offers applications for consumption (by means of installation) on devices under a business model of their choice (e.g. retail, direct, free, etc). * Provides application lifecycle management. * Manages application developer relations.

role.name: Application Service Provider of hosted webinos Application
role.description: * Runs webinos Applications in the cloud on behalf of a webinos Application user. * Offers hosted instances of webinos platform components.

role.name: Device Manufacturer
role.description: Offers execution environment for the webinos runtime. * Supports webinos discovery functionality for devices and applications. * Demands webinos to add tangible user benefit by means of making webinos applications available on their devices.

role.name: Network Provider
role.description: Of Internet Connectivity (not local / short-range connectivity). * Provides and manages access to the internet for users as well as for application service providers.

role.name: 3rd Party Service Provider
role.description: Supplies functionality outside of the webinos platform and functions set to webinos App Developers which they can use in their Apps.

asset.name: Context Query
asset.significance: Poorly-defined queries may return privacy-invasive data

asset.name: Event
asset.description: An object incorporating messaging attributes and additional webinos specific payload data and meta-data
asset.significance: Event messaging attributes are potentially spoofable. Vulnerabilities intrinsic to the underlying technology, e.g. XMPP, JSON, also weaken webinos events.

security_property.rationale: Events should only be interpretable by authorised events.
Loss of event data leads to gradual degradation of webinos services and any applications depending on these events.

asset.name: PZH Proxy
asset.significance: Proxy through which messages are sent to the PZH Provider

asset.name: XML HTTP Request
asset.significance: Channel used to send messages between components.

asset.name: Relying Party
asset.significance: Data used to establish identity with openid provider

asset.name: JSON Object
asset.significance: Encapsulates data sent between components within the same node process

asset.name: Farm Configuration
asset.significance: Stores connection parameters for PZH Provider TLS server

asset.name: OpenID credentials
asset.significance: Used to authenticate to a PZH Provider

security_property.rationale: Credentials may be misused for other purposes.

asset.name: Certificate
asset.significance: TLS relies on PZP and PZH certificates

asset.name: Certificate Signing Request
asset.description: A message sent from an applicant to a certificate authority in order to apply for a digital identity certificate.

asset.name: Enrollment Token
asset.description: Token generated by PZH in order that a PZP can be enrolled into a personal zone.
asset.significance: Access to the token provides a means for unauthorised devices to be enroled into a personal zone.

asset.name: TV Source
asset.description: List of channels with a name

asset.name: Configuration Document
asset.description: The XML vocabulary that declares metadata and configuration parameters for a widget.
asset.significance: Characterises the provenance of an application

security_property.rationale: This asset assigns responsibility to the application.

asset.name: ZIP Archive
asset.description: Archive conforming to PKWare ZIP specification.
asset.significance: Archives might contain things other than webinos applications.

asset.name: Widget Signature
asset.significance: Verifies the data integrity of the files within the widget package and confirms the signing key.

security_property.rationale: Needs to exist to allow developer authentication and validation of code integrity.

asset.name: Start File
asset.description: A file from the widget package to be loaded by the user agent when it instantiates the widget.
asset.significance: Loaded each time an application starts.

asset.name: File
asset.description: A decompressed physical representation of a file entry.

asset.name: Icon
asset.description: File used to represent the widget in various application contexts; this helps users of visual browsers recognise the widget at a glance.
asset.significance: Loaded each time an application starts.

asset.name: WARP File
asset.description: Extension to the configuration document controlling network access from within a widget.
asset.significance: Stipulate origins that widget can access, and defines author expectations for resources needed by application.

asset.name: Personal Zone Administration Console
asset.description: The web interface used to control the personal zone.
asset.significance: Used to authenticate significant actions in the personal zone, such as revoking and adding devices and connecting to other users.

security_property.rationale: Losing access to the PZH Admin console would result in many features being offline, as well as preventing users from responding to attacks or revoking malicious devices
Because the administration console can be used to add and remove webinos devices and alter policies, accountability of who performed the actions is important.

asset.name: Identity Provider
asset.description: Interface through which an Identity Provider registers and provides authentication credentials.
asset.significance: webinos may fall back on a less secure backup if this is not available.

asset.name: Device API
asset.significance: Manipulates device features and accesses privacy-sensitive data

security_property.rationale: Changes made to the API need to be tracked to make sure only authorised entities can do this.

asset.name: TLS Server
asset.significance: Responsible for TLS communication between personal zone components

asset.name: Web Server
asset.significance: Provides web interface to PZH provider

asset.name: WebSocket Server
asset.significance: Responsible for communication between personal zone components

asset.name: Widget Processor
asset.significance: Responsible for implementing the widget installation logic

asset.name: Widget Validator
asset.significance: Responsible for validating the digital signature of the packages

asset.name: Configuration Processor
asset.significance: Encapsulates the algorithm responsible for checking the contents of the widget configuration file

asset.name: Widget Persistence
asset.significance: Responsible for physically deploying the contents of the widget package and creating the requisite directory structure.

asset.name: Widget Package
asset.description: Client side application packaged for distribution.

persona.name: Alice
persona.activities:
TV rocks Alice's world. Alice loves watching national and international TV, and, after work each day, enjoys nothing more than browsing some of the more esoteric TV channels from around the world, from Japanese Sci-Fi to Angus Buchan sermons in South Africa.
At home, her TV home entertainment system takes central stage in her social life, to the extent that her primary means of web-surfing and viewing photographs is the TV.
Alice is part of an online community of fellow TV addicts. She provides online services with details of her preferences, and allows services to keep track of her viewing habits. She is rewarded with suggestions about programmes of interest to her. Specifically, the selection available is based on her viewing history and the interests of others with similar viewing characteristics.
persona.attitudes:
To feed her TV addiction, Alice has built her own home-entertainment system. The system is an elaborate pipeline of different components, with eclectic input sources such as satellite dishes and PCs streaming programme information, and output devices such as speakers and, of course, her TV.
Her interests have made her technically adept enough to examine the specification of devices she might want to purchase to ensure they meet her quality of service expectations, and are compatible with her "cloud" of devices.
persona.aptitudes:
To feed her TV addiction, Alice has built her own home-entertainment system. The system is an elaborate pipeline of different components, with eclectic input sources such as satellite dishes and PCs streaming programme information, and output devices such as speakers and, of course, her TV.
Her interests have made her technically adept enough to examine the specification of devices she might want to purchase to ensure they meet her quality of service expectations, and are compatible with her "cloud" of devices.
persona.motivations: Alice likes to spend as much quality time as possible watching the TV, and has optimised the hardware in her lounge around this goal. When Alice wants to change channel, she will reach for whichever device is closest to her; this is invariably her smart phone, although she recently repurposed an old handset to see if she could use this as a remote as well! If Alice needs to use the web or chat online, she will re-purpose her desktop's wireless keyboard and use the TV has her monitor. To facilitate this, Alice makes sure her TV and peripheral devices are modern enough to be discoverable by her controlling applications.
persona.skills: Alice is comfortable configuring Audio-Visual equipment. This includes transcoding media from one format to another, configuring software for streaming over her home LAN, and setting up TV and satellite feeds into her home entertainment system.

persona_environment.name: Transfer and Management of State
persona_environment.narrative: Alice subscribes to several music and video online services. She also stores data on cloud-based services like Dropbox and Google docs. Alice has never had any bad experiences with the web and, as such, is comfortable with using the web for storing personal and device specific data, and is happy for web services to use this data to help manage her lifestyle.

persona.name: Anna
persona.activities:
Anna is in the final year of an undergraduate medical degree. Breathing difficulties, coupled with a very mild form of Cerebral Palsy mean that some of her motor skills are limited and she is prone to bouts of fatigue. Because of her restricted mobility, Anna is dependent on the use of a wheel-chair.
Despite her disability, Anna is keen on socialising, and lives in an adapted halls of residence at her university, so she can get out and meet people.
persona.attitudes:
Although Anna had problems studying with her disabilities in school, her expectations about the accessibility of places, processes, and things have been raised during her time at university. These were raised in line with her desire to be more independent. Her local authority provides her access to a Personal Assistant when she occasionally needs help with shopping or other physically demanding activities, and she finds that many shops and places around university are becoming more accessible. As a result, Anna expects software and systems to be accessible enough for her to use.
As the world around her has become more accessible, Anna has grown to dislike being type-casted because she relies on a wheel-chair. When she can, as much for exercise as anything else, she will try to walk short distances without a wheel-chair. Moreover, as her graduation approaches, she has become increasingly wary of highlighting her disability too greatly. With the current economic crisis, Anna is concerned she might miss out on jobs if her CV or an application form suggests she might be too much of a burden.
persona.aptitudes:
Anna's desire for independence has given her a sharp eye for identifying ways that technology can improve her mobility. To reduce her reliance on her Personal Assistant constantly visiting her, she uses her mobile to keep in touch with her if she needs something. She also uses an electric wheelchair to get around, and is on the look out for any technology which might improve her studies and way of life, even if she has to pay for it herself because her local authority will not.
Anna realises, however, that she does not live in a perfect world and needs to forward plan if she does anything which she thinks might be out of the ordinary. If Anna needs to take a bus, she tries to find out if she can take a wheel-chair on it before she ventures out. Anna also tries to find out if new shops are accessible before she first visits them, especially when buying clothes; she does not want to find something she likes only to discover that there is nowhere accessible to try it on.
persona.motivations:
Being disabled, Anna often needs to deal with a lot of bureaucracy to get the care she needs, and would love for some of this to be automated. She is convinced that technology can help her reduce the amount of forms she invariably needs to complete to get her benefits, or the number of people she has to deal with in local government or her university to resolve issues which occasionally crop up.
Despite her self confidence, Anna always needs to think about what happens when things go wrong. Getting wheel-chair problems when out and about can leave her stranded because she struggles when walking more than a short distance.

persona.name: Clara
persona.activities: Clara is a teenager who lives with her family. Clara has diabetes and in order to live a good life, she actively manages her diabetes by herself. For this purpose, she uses modern technology, such as a laptop and a smartphone. Together with her blood glucose meter she collects and stores the measured data on a cloud service which is accessible by her physician.
persona.attitudes: Like most of the teenagers of her age, Clara wants to enjoy her life and have fun. She goes out with friends, eats unhealthy things and has an irregular daily routine. Being distracted by all the interesting things around her, she often forgets to measure her blood glucose level. As a result, her glucose level is too high on average. This is dangerous to her health. Even though her physician emphasises the importance of a good glucose level and the risks of a high glucose level, she is not caring enough. In fact, Clara is willing to manage her disease but she also does not want to give up the fun part of her life. Currently, she tends more to the fun part than to healthcare. She did not find her balance yet, but she is in the process of learning to cope with her disease.

persona.name: David
persona.activities:
From early age, David has been involved in a number of challenging (legal and illegal) activities. However, his minor sporting successes have not brought a very comfortable or profitable life. He has spent a significant part of his life as a young adult in jail.
His actual work as skilled car mechanics has positive facets: raised in a household of mechanics and car experts, he finds the work easy, and he can effortlessly achieve very good results in repairing cars. However, his troubled nature prevents him from being satisfied and he is unable to foresee a bright career.
persona.attitudes:
David was raised in family where talking about cars was the norm. His parents allowed his love of racing vehicles to bloom.
Another parental (David's father's, in particular) gift was the negative influence (build up on the father's disciplinary extremes) that cursed him with a youth of disorder and an unbalanced personality. This resulted in an inclination to commit crimes, break laws and rules, and be violent.
Some sporting achievements have made him fairly popular, but have had the unfortunate side-effect of encouraging his illegal activities: his self-confidence increased as well as his attraction to hazardous activities.
Due to his careless attitude and lack of consideration for consequences, he can perform actions that have potentially dreadful impact on others and possibly also to himself.
persona.aptitudes: His upbringing gifted him with a good competence in the working and internals of cars as he was involved in daily car trouble-shooting and discussion. This love for talking about cars and problem-solving led him to open and maintain a blog where car problems are dissected. Often, David give good advice and pretty good solutions to a problem in comprehensible and effective manner, due to his disposition to break up problems into simpler terms.
persona.motivations:
David loves to be fast, he feels all life should be passed at increasing speed. In this sense, a growing feeling of non-satisfaction is growing within him. David's present work is boring, his pockets are empty (difficult to have any savings if you come and go from prison). Furthermore, he recently lost a chance of a career move.
A way to possibly collect some money more is tampering. Clever tampering! "Selective" tampering! Meaning a kind of damage that causes vehicles to develop a problem after some time, possibly in different parts. This means that he will be asked to fix a number of problems that happen at the same time, resulting in more work and even some well-paid overtime.
persona.skills: Apart car aptitudes, David also has some IT skills. David is quite familiar with company's communication system and with vulnerability exploitation.

persona_environment.name: Transfer and Management of State
persona_environment.narrative:
David has a deranged personality, and is not fully capable of evaluating the consequences of his actions. This is true also in terms of his own personal damage. His actions can lead to devasting result for himself, as the years in prison have demonstrated.
On the other hand, he is also fairly clever (in a frenzied way). His plan to tamper with car systems (including on board computers) has a non-negligible chance of success, at least in the short term. In the longer term, David will very likely face some more time in the local penitentiary.

persona.name: Eric
persona.activities: Eric is Helen's 5 year old son. Although not a webinos user as such, he does use sometimes use his mother's webinos-enabled tablet device when going on journeys. Although Helen usually thinks about what Eric might do for long journeys, he is usually left to his own devices on short-duration trips like school-runs or shopping trips.
persona.attitudes: Eric enjoys activities which draw the attention of others, and likes to involve other people in the games that he plays. For this reason, Eric is particularly fond of playing simple games with his parents, such as I Spy.
persona.aptitudes: As Eric has grown older, he has also developed an interest in activities which absorb his interest. Card and memory games have been known to keep Eric distracted on long journeys. Similarly, Eric is happy to watch films and take a snooze when feels a little tired.
persona.motivations: Eric focuses his energies on whatever technology he has to hand, but always looks for instant gratification based on his current needs. Although he finds tables and touch-screens intriguing, he is prone to throwing down objects he doesn't like. Eric will tolerate things he doesn't find immediately useful only if he expects a reward as a consequence of using it. If Eric is going on long journeys, he takes comfort in his things which are familiar to him. For example, Helen often gives Eric his teddy bear when travelling long distances, such as to a theme park or trips to his grandparents, and is usually unable to sleep on car journeys without this. Although Eric doesn't hold his teddy bear all the time, he becomes distressed if unable to reach for this at any time from his seat.

persona.name: Ethan
persona.activities: Ethan is a student just like many others: he has no particular problems or outstanding successes. Unlike many others, he believes that taking some shortcuts (of dubious legality) can be of some help. In order to gain some extra spending-money and fill his always-empty student pockets, he devotes part of his time to earning money illegally as a spammer. One of his activities, for example, is sending messages on behalf of individuals who sell counterfeit good, or participating in an email campaign for a "pump and dump" scheme.
persona.attitudes: Much like many other students, Ethan does not have a strong inclination toward rules and laws. In fact, he has a quite pronounced inclination toward illicit activities that can be more or less remunerative. However, he still doesn't want to get in trouble with the law, he is just willing to risk it because he wants money even more.
persona.aptitudes: Ethan has cultivated some of the essential skills for his fraudulent network activities. His habitual tasks consist in looking for vulnerable networks, exploiting such vulnerabilities and then gathering data from those non security-savvy systems. Whenever possible and whenever he thinks it is not too risky, he enjoys accessing and taking control of vulnerable systems and harvesting data from vulnerable targets. When successful, this often includes usernames, passwords, and also details of credit cards that have been illicitly gained by other malicious intruders. This information can be profitably used for trading of credit card number (good offers for them in Black Market) and for circumvent monitoring system and anti-spam filters.
persona.motivations: He wants easy money, since in his opinion it is very rarely the most tiresome way that is the best one. During his student career, he has found it difficult to make much money in legal ways. Since he already has a botnet at his service, why not use it for some additional source of wealth? Being a botnet administrator has many other benefits. For example, he can attack politicians with whom he disagrees. After all, Ethan has some sense of civic responsibility in his own way.
persona.skills: Ethan most important skills lies in the administrator-level knowledge of a botnet, and on the knowledge of how exploit it for illicit spamming activities and other illicit activities using them. For these reasons, knowledge of using spamming tools is of benefit to his business.

persona_environment.narrative: Ethan does not want a blemish on his CV. He knows enough on the security postures of his targets to be reasonably safe from problems. persona.name: Frankie
persona.activities: Frankie is an alienated computer addict. He started using computer at the age of six, when he was troubled by the separation of his parents, and all his life has been centered on computers ever since. Up to now, he has had a quite normal student career, without any notable brilliance or related achievements.
persona.attitudes:
He never established strong friendships and can only express himself through computers. Since computers have been his main friends, he has failed to pick up some society norms and values, including commonly known laws and rules.
The parent's separation gave him an inner sense of rage and frustration, making him quarrelsome and vexatious. Sadly, he is just looking for attention and support, but he's not able to express this to anyone in person.
His present hobbys involve malicious computer actions, however, his knowledge of security is naive, and he can only us publicly-available tools for exploiting systems. He is constantly seeking attention and recognition and usually brags about his stunts on internet. This gains him only disregard from his victims and scorn from real security experts.
persona.aptitudes: The very early emotional trauma he suffered deprived him of his motivation to learn. He just wants attention, but no one has taught him the right way to get self-esteem. So, he learns to take the easy option and the "fast way" toward his goals, not understanding the fruitfulness of the longer ones. He is involved in a number of licit or illicit tasks (Wi-F cracking, virus spreading) but he has no more than a superficial knowledge and interest in any of them.
persona.motivations: He wants to damage others and gain money in order to attract attention, and achieve a fake sense of control in a otherwise unhappy and unimportant life.
persona.skills: He has an understanding of computers and Internet, but due to his lack of motivation for education and learning, his knowledge is only a little above average, especially regarding public (or almost public) domain software used to hack networks.

persona_environment.name: Transfer and Management of State
persona_environment.narrative:
He does not have any respect of the privacy of others. Essentially, due to his scarce human relationships, he does not really understand motivation of privacy and of many human rights.
Since his university is quite open and trust students, it exposes naive weaknesses that even a poor attacker like Frankie can exploit and trespass security policies.

persona.name: Gary
persona.activities: Presently unemployed, recently fired, not in a very happy mood. Gary angrily remembers his former career as task leader of the information technology unit, working for over 25 years in desktop and networking support, and building a professional websites for more than 10 years. Until he was discharged without consideration of his long-serving loyalty to the company's work.
persona.attitudes: An experienced PC user, who happily uses a PC for everyday tasks. His always demands new challenges capable of stimulating his natural curiosity and matching his desire for personal improvement. In particular, he enjoys improving his knowledge of computers and the Internet every day.
persona.aptitudes: Already fed by a good knowledge of PC and Internet, he can easily prove the obtained knowledge through many certificates related to his job. However, despite his existing achievements he still has a desire to obtain new certification as evidence of his tireless appetite for learning.
persona.motivations: Due to the perceived unjust treatment by his former employer, Gary first idea is to retaliate for his dismissal by deleting company data. After a second thought, the idea remains the same! It is impossible for him to forgive such insensitive behaviour by the company. Since he is able to access the computer system, a huge amount of damage is eagerly achievable.
persona.skills: Gary knows the company's internal network and his old user account is still working (the company should have disabled it promptly, but did not). He can directly access and delete relevant files or embed a malicious script in a routine program to plant a logic bomb on the company server.

persona_environment.name: Transfer and Management of State
persona_environment.narrative: Gary knows relatively little about security. Even if the security posture of its organization is not very well shaped (his non-disabled account is the best proof of this), he still left an obvious trace of his actions in the system. As a result, his actions are destined to drive him in front of a court of justice.

persona.name: Gloria
persona.activities: Gloria likes using personalised services which help her organising her tasks. This holds for Internet-based services as well as for services offered by shops, restaurants and others. To ease her life with her allergies, she uses her mobile phone and related services to find food she can eat. Her profession is policy decision maker. She is an employee of an e-book store, deciding and implementing access and distribution policies for e-books.
persona.attitudes: In order to extract interesting offers she likes filtering the vast amount of offers by subscribing for information about promotions and special deals of her favourite shops. She also participates in providing useful information by writing recommendations for restaurants. On her job, it is important for her to provide attractive products. She wants her customers to enjoy reading their e-books. In her policies she allows them to read their books on any of their devices.
persona.motivations: Her private life -- her hobbies and her interests -- is what she is living for. Everything else is centred around. She enjoys shopping and dining out. She uses mobile devices and mobile services if they improve her experience of her interests. Her hobbies are even more important than her friends. She seems to enjoy herself best when she is alone. Presumably she is a single. Her job appears to provide her with enough money to be spent on her hobbies.

persona.name: Helen
persona.activities:
Helen is a 32 year old marketing manager for a publishing house in Brighton.
Helen has a 3 year old toddler, Eric, which she drops off at the nursery on the way to work each morning, and picks up at a fixed time on her way home. This is something Helen has to do because Scott, her husband, works in the City, so catches a train to and from work.
persona.attitudes:
Helen feels strongly about her role as a mother of a young family. Even though her job can be quite stressful and demanding time-wise, she feels it's important to maintain a healthy work-life balance. For this reason, she works regular office hours (partly to make sure she can drop off her child to/from the nursery, works with work media at the office only and, unlike most of her friends, LinkedIn is the only social network she uses at work.
The only time Helen transfers media between devices is when she is in the office and doing things like tranferring presentations and documents between PCs and laptops. Helen does, however, use the cloud to store snaps that she has taken of her family.
persona.aptitudes: Although Helen wouldn't call herself technically literate, she has become quite adept at using the technology around her to streamline her working life. She uses a blue-tooth hands-free phone in her car, and makes sure the calendar on her phone (with both work and home calendar) is kept synchronised with her work laptop, PC, and the home media system her husband has setup.
persona.motivations: Helen works hard to make sure her day-to-day life is as predictable as possible. Because of this, Helen wants to rely on the context-awareness features in her applications. She wants her data to be synchronised when it needs to be, and to be prompted when she (invariably) forgets things.
persona.intrinsic: Helen's concern about her family can sometimes cloud her judgement or lead her to make access control decisions that, in the cold light of day, might not be best for her or Eric. On a good day, however, Helen has an eye for seeing intricacies in contexts, and appreciating the sort of things that strangers might want to take advantage of.
persona.contextual: Thinking explicitly about how her family interacts with technology helps Helen think about how to access control data associated with these interactions. Also, because little details that complicate thinking, Helen uses things like sketches and abstractions to support the access control decision making process.

persona.name: Irwin
persona.activities: Irwin is employed by a company that manufactures aircraft hardware and turbine engine components. He has access to trade secrets information. He has the help of his colleagues who consider him a trustworthy person.
persona.attitudes: He is married and father of three. He is described by friends as having a quiet sense of humor and as an excellent competitive ballroom dancer. He has signed a confidentiality agreement with his employer, and on exit interview he will be expected to sign a document promising the return of any information considered to be a trade secret. However, he breaks both of these agreements.
persona.aptitudes: He provides policy statements to identify trade secrets within the company and to protect those trade secrets. He has a good learning inclination.
persona.motivations: He wants to earn money from his company and from the competitor. Alternatively, he wants to get a more lucrative work at rival company.
persona.skills: He has good knowledge of organization security posture and good knowledge of computer languages.

persona.name: Jessica
persona.activities:
Jessica lives and works in California. She is in charge of developing a mobile application for diabetes, and a business co-founder. The diabetes application is being written for iPhone and Android platforms. The diabetes application is easy to use. Many diabetes people who are not computer-addicted are using it. It enables the planning, monitoring, and follow-up of diabetes patients via smart-phones. The application captures blood sugar and insulin measurements, and reminds the patient about when to do the measurements. All personal and medical data is also relayed and stored securely in an online application server, with a back office for diabetes research professionals. There is also a patented diet calculator included in the mobile application. The application was the winner of the "Apps for Medicare" competition at the White House, in Washington, DC, in 2010, because it has been embraced by the Diabetes community, General Practitioners, and Insurance Companies. She has based the data models on the HL7-standard as much as possible. A stringent and flexible privacy policy, in which the individual diabetes patient is in full control of who can access and use the data, has been a requirement for the patients to trust the system. In the picture above she is in the medicare technology conference where she received the "Apps for Medicare" award.
She is a traditional application developer that develops software clients for two smart-phone platforms. She keeps herself up-to-date on new technologies, applies them when writing new software and she knows what the competitors are doing. She is a diligent person, and carefully implements and tests the applications and she wants to understand the technologies before applying them. As a member of HL7, she is also a privacy-aware developer. She is very committed, systematic, and organised. She helps people make informed choices about their health. She likes to structure information and data, elicit requirements, and to delegate some tasks to the user and other tasks to the system. She communicates with a variety of people working with diabetes treatment, care, and research. She is a user-conscious developer, involving users as participants in her work, and she also has a user forum. Although she is user-centred she has a preference to mix it with model-driven development techniques, too. She models tasks and domain objects. She also models the context of use - as means to understand the users' everyday activities surrounding their diabetes problem.
persona.attitudes:
Creating trust, keeping her promises, and maintaining integrity are key values for Jessica. Being able to help other people means a lot for her. After her graduation she worked three years as engineer for United Nations and Save the Children in Africa to help governments and people. When she came back to the US, she realised she wanted to continue helping people with their health problems. She contacted some other like-minded through the university alumni, co-founded the company, got venture capital onboard in the round A funding, and further institutional investors from the health insurance sector onboard in round B. Integrity and customer-intimacy are key values for Jessica, and this is why the investors have been backing in her. She is very likeable and social one-on-one, but quite private and shy in larger crowds.
Although technically strong, she dislikes HTML and web development. Jessica feels that making more of the system open on the web implies much less control over the UI. She also believes the system becomes more open to attackers in general so her system must be very secure, have 100% uptime, and adhere to the best privacy policies. She also needs full control over every pixel on the screen, and the connection to the insulin meter.
persona.aptitudes: Jessica isn't athletic, but she is naturally talented at maths. She uses her maths skills to draw 2D and 3D graphics and curves in ways that some of her colleagues are unable to grasp. She enjoys integrating with low-level sensors, visualising medical data as 3D-charts, and in encoding and decoding data. Her natural talent for plotting such data on the screen, are one of the reasons to the product success.
persona.motivations:
She is highly motivated by the desire to engage and interact with patients, relatives, and healthcare professionals. As a result, she goes to great lengths to ensure her customers are happy. It inspires her to be able to spend many consecutive hours per day in front of her laptops to improve the applications using Eclipse and XCode. She becomes even more committed, the closer she gets to a user forum meeting.
Jessica burns to deliver the perfect, robust product. She frequently tests the applications. Being able to help each individual certainly boosts her energy level. Progress and improvement makes her happy, while misery and deterioration makes her anxious and less effective.
Jessica considers reduced quality of data as a direct threat to their business. Errors and loss of data over time could lead to a court case, or media coverage, which could bring the entire company to the brink. Storing the same data at multiple locations is a solution for them. Privacy is important.
persona.skills:
Jessica is a specialist in Objective C and Java programming. She writes Objective C code in XCode for the iPhone app, and Java for Dalvik on Android. Jessica is also familiar with information visualisation and UI widget libraries associated with iPhone and Android platforms.
Jessica is adept at working with many hand-sets, but is unfamiliar with Nokia and Sony Ericsson hand-set development because she has never had need to do this.

persona_environment.name: Transfer and Management of State
persona_environment.narrative: Jessica's diabetes application has 750000 users in which 60% are on iPhone and 40% are on Android. She is legally obliged to protect all of the personal and medical data, and to make sure that the patients, relatives, and healthcare professionals are kept up-to-date with the data from each patient. One risk is that patients incorrectly read the insulin dosage due to visual impairment. Another risk is that the measurements on blood sugar and insulin measurements are simply incorrect or has a wrong time stamp. If this happens over a consecutive period of time, then this may trigger fake alarms, incorrect treatments, or lead to serious health issues.

persona.name: Jimmy
persona.activities:
Jimmy's life is software development and Internet services. He is a self-employed professional software developer for mobile applications but he also spends his leisure time on writing plug-ins for his home equipment.
Jimmy is a passionate and experienced professional software developer. His focus is on mobile applications and Web applications. His experience covers the iPhone, Android and further technologies. He writes new applications and ports them to different platforms. He does software development for quite some years. Apart from that, he is a passionate and successful blogger.
persona.attitudes: When developing software, Jimmy prefers open source. For him it is important to control what is going on in the software he uses. He chooses his tool chain and makes architectural decisions for his software accordingly. He keeps all the source code he once wrote and reuses fragments of it in other projects whenever it makes sense. For him, his source code is his own treasury of valuables he has created in his life. He always wants to have access to it and reuse whenever useful. He has no notion of braking the law by this behaviour. He just wants to implement good and working applications without reimplementing things he already implemented.
persona.aptitudes: Jimmy follows a pragmatic hands-on design and implementation approach. He is much more into trying out things rather than spending time on theory. As he is interested in new technologies and new market opportunities he always stays up-to-date in his field. Jimmy enjoys experimenting with new technology and he adapts quickly. He learns best by just trying out things. Apart from that, he knows how to make money from the applications he writes, as he sells some mobile applications on an application store.
persona.motivations: Jimmy is font of software-controlled gadgets which interact with other devices on his home network. He makes use of his professional knowledge to implement plug-ins and extensions for his home equipment. This allows him to let all the devices do what he needs.
persona.skills: Jimmy implements low-level functional details. Since he has deep knowledge on how things work, he can reverse-engineer software and take special features of target devices into account.
persona.intrinsic:
Jimmy uses his standard design and development tools and processes to model and make sense of security issues. Sometimes he finds thinking about security tedious, and will re-use settings and designs where he thinks this is appropriate. This seems more efficient than thinking deeply about intricate details.
Although the different ways his software might be used can be overwhelming, thinking about them gets him thinking about what some of his target users might go through when setting up and running his applications. At times, however, this appreciation can lead him to make decisions which err too much towards their freedom of action rather than the best decision given their implicit security and privacy expectations.
persona.contextual:
Thinking about the many different contexts can be taxing, particularly given the tools available to Jimmy are not a perfect fit for this job. Unfortunately, different contexts are not Jimmy's only worry. The problems associated with things like categorising and structuring security information, and the discussions sometimes Jimmy has to have with colleagues, means making any sort of security design decision can forever.
These considerations mean that, in the cold light of day, Jimmy is forced to make decisions that might lead to inappropriate user behaviours. This causes some angst when having to trade-off user freedom with what he considers an appropriate level of security when deciding default settings.

persona_environment.narrative: Jimmy is experienced in software security to some extent. He configures his home equipment to be accessible from the Internet, but it is protected by access control. On the other hand, he does not like to be limited by access control while using his computer and while implementing software.

persona.name: Justin
persona.activities:
Justin is a young, hip trendsetter who is constantly active and loves using cutting edge technology. He has a lucrative job (a trader in the city) and plenty of spare cash. He's always busy and uses his mobile (and many applications) to schedule his life. his interests are in cars, technology, music and fashion.
Justin commutes frequently and is also a keen runner, cyclist and does plenty of exercise.
persona.attitudes:
For Justin, style is everything. He cares deeply about his appearance and the way his personal effects look. He does not mind spending money on things that look good.
Justin is very busy and constantly multitasking. He uses technology to keep himself up to date and fill in the gaps in his schedule.
He trusts technology and is happy to share data with many people through it.
persona.aptitudes: Justin is cutting edge, constantly buying new gadgets. He is fairly technology savvy, although he does not necessarily know much about the risks he faces online.
persona.motivations:
His motivations are pleasure and style: he cares about appearance and buying things that absolutely meet his specifications.
He also tries to fit a lot of activities into the day in order to keep up with his numerous interests.

persona_environment.narrative: Justin doesn't care much for his own privacy or personal data; he is just happy to get new features and gadgets, and is indifferent about spending money to satiate his whims. persona.name: Peter
persona.activities:
Peter is an older gentleman, single and without many family commitments. He is fairly wealthy and enjoys spending his time and money on his interests: music, art and cars. He has a senior position at a large financial company, but when he is out of work he rarely thinks about his job.
Peter collects all the objects related to his interests - albums, paintings and cars - and would like to increase his access to them through new technology.
persona.attitudes:
Peter's well-paid job has allowed him to concentrate on the things that he loves: art, music and his main obsession: cars.
Peter likes using technology to further these interests. He spends considerable amounts of his leisure time driving, reading about cars and buying accessories and upgrades. He expects technology to help bridge the gap between his interests, so that he can enjoy art and music while on the move. Peter's lack of family commitments allows him to spend even more time on his hobbies. He relies on technology to let him organise and use his enormous music collection.
persona.aptitudes:
Peter is familiar with technology and no stranger to electronic media such as music and radio.
Peter is patient with technology and is willing to explore a new interface and follow pop-up instructions before he achieves his main objectives.
persona.motivations: Peter is primarily interest-driven. He wants to use technology to bring his interests to his daily commute as well as letting him enjoy art and music whenever he has a spare moment, or whenever he comes across something new that he likes.
persona.skills: Peter has a reasonable amount of experience with different forms of technology, particularly in using multimedia systems.

persona.name: Richard
persona.activities: Richard spends about half of his time at his desk; the other half is spent on duty in the community. He works and interacts with technology at set times, and is prescribed by the policies and tools employed by his station. Although his working hours are pre-determined, the nature of shift work means he might work on different days, and different times of day. Being a policeman is a physically demanding, and the technology accompanying him can be "put through its paces". As a result, technology is prone to breakage or loss, and subsequent replacement.
persona.attitudes: Like many security professionals, Richard is conservative by nature; he prefers the "tried and tested" over the novel and unknown. As a figure of authority, he embraces authority, and serving the community gives him a high sense of self-worth and assertiveness. However, working with the less desirable aspects of society has also made Richard cynical and suspicious of outsiders. Consequently, Richard can be quick to jump to conclusions, an attribute he chalks up to experience, but others may see as prejudicial. Richard's pragmatism filters through to his attitude to technology: either it does the job or not; if it works he'll use it, if it doesn't he won't.
persona.aptitudes: To effectively perform his duties, Richard needs to be emotionally stable, and approaching any problems with a calm and rationale manner. Some of these duties are less glamorous than others, so a low boredom threshold helps. Working with the public on a day-to-day basis also requires a certain affinity with people, intuitively empathising when required and asserting his authority when needed.
persona.motivations: Like any professional, Richard wants to do well at his job, to get noticed and get the next promotions. On a day-to-day basis this means being efficient and effective. The technology that supports him does not have to be perfect, the UI does not have to be sleek; Richard will put up with a lot of "irritations" as long at the technology does the job effectively. Richard is burdened by the administration that plagues his working life. Anything that enables him to spend less time in the office and more time on the streets doing his job is a good thing.
persona.skills: Richard has acquired his skills through his training and professional development. The skills of organisation, memory and observation are base skills every policeman is grounded in and Richard has these in abundance. Richard tolerates routine, and understand and values the need for clear procedure in his daily habits. Richard is a fast decision maker and can follow this through with the public and his work colleague, demonstrating leadership.

task.name: Remote Monitoring of Chronic Disease through Acces
task.author: Claes Nilsson, Dieter Blomme

task_environment.name: Discovery and Addressing
task_environment.narrative:
As the lifespan of people is growing, the number of people having at least one chronic disease is increasing. Personal medical sensors and mobile communication could play a big role for the treatment of chronically ill persons and also improve their quality of life. Furthermore, sensors and mobile communication makes remote monitoring possible, which is convenient for the patients and saves money for healthcare providers.
In the following story, Clara is a teenager with diabetes. She uses her favorite blood glucose meter to measure her blood glucose levels. This meter is also able to communicate with internet connected computing devices such as her laptop and her mobile smart phone through a standardized local communication method (USB, Bluetooth, BLE, ANT+ etc).
Clara has found several interesting cloud-based web applications for diabetics. These applications help Clara analyzing her blood glucose levels so that she can control her disease. The applications could for example display all her glucose levels for a certain time period, display diagrams showing average values throughout a day, show statistics on glucose levels within target/below target/above target, etc. She runs these web applications not only on her laptop but also on her mobile smart phone as well as on the family's internet connected TV. When she runs the applications they discover that there is connectivity with her blood glucose meter and all values stored in the meter are transferred to the computing device and are processed by the diabetes web application. Clara's blood glucose meter can be used by any diabetes web application that fulfills any standardized manner to retrieve values from the blood glucose meter.
The most common case is that the blood glucose meter is connected to the computing device and values are transferred when Clara starts the diabetes web application. It is also possible to have a continuous connection so that each measured value is instantly sent to the computing device. This is especially applicable for future non-invasive (checking blood glucose levels without puncturing the skin for a blood sample) continuous blood glucose meters. For elderly and possibly demented diabetics who are not capable of understanding and acting on blood sugar values by themselves continuous blood sugar measurement with instant transmission to a wireless connected computing device and further direct uploading to a health care provider web service may be necessary.
A webinos enabled diabetes web application also has the possibility to store Clara's blood glucose values in a diabetes file in the cloud. It is important that this file is stored in a secure manner and that no unauthorized third parties have access to it. The file could be shared with her health care provider based on Clara's decision. For example, all values handled by the diabetes web application could continuously be stored in her diabetes file in the cloud and be made available to her endocrinologist, her nurse, her dietitian, etc. This would for example allow the doctor to spot persistent out-of-normal-range episodes early. The doctor and other medical parties could also update the diabetes file with information from the laboratory e.g. HBA1c (which reflects the average blood glucose level during the last 2 - 3 month period), provide recommendations on modifications to the diet or medication and remind Clara of important upcoming events such as the expiration of prescriptions.
Alternatively, Clara can make her results available when she visits her diabetes doctor for her three-monthly check-up. A scenario can be that Clara takes out her mobile phone and starts her webinos diabetes web application. She goes to the Sharing my file page. The application automatically searches for webinos enabled devices in the vicinity. The doctor's mobile phone shows up on the list and webinos automatically provides Clara with the necessary data to check the security of sharing the file. Clara can then choose to share her file with the doctor using this mobile phone. Now the doctor gets a notification on his mobile phone and his PC that Clara has shared her file with him and he can now check the results and update the file where applicable.
task_environment.consequences:
* Users are not able to run web applications such as a diabetes web application that automatically retrieves data from a sensor such as a blood glucose meter in the proximity of the device.
* There is currently no easy way for web application developers to create applications that access sensors in the proximity of the device. Only a few specialized APIs to access native functionality exist, e.g. the W3C Geolocation API.
* New types of sensors are invented all the time. There is no system for providing web developers with easy access to sensor data in a generic manner.
* Users want medical data to be secure. This is a major issue for data stored in the cloud. No unprivileged access should be given to third parties.
* The sharing of the medical file should be authorized only by the end user, who is the owner of the file. No third parties should be able to edit the sharing and access settings.
task_environment.benefits:
* The User is able to use her favorite sensor-aware web application, e.g. a diabetes web application, with any favorite sensor of the type that the web application needs, e.g. a blood glucose meter.
* Data from new sensors that are invented will be available to web applications.
* The user is able to share sensitive data, e.g. medical data, in a secure manner with all relevant parties.

task.name: Usable Privacy Controls for webinos
task.author: Ajit Jaokar, John Lyle, Shamal Faily, Ivan Flechais, Hans Myrhaug, Ayse Goker
task.objective: A chance alert leads to Gloria updating her webinos privacy preferences.\n

task_environment.name: Policy and Security
task_environment.narrative:
Gloria has a webinos-compatible mobile phone and car, and owns several online identities; she is particular keen on keeping her work and personal life separate. When using her mobile phone for work she uses her LinkedIn identity, and during the weekends she moves to a Facebook-provided identity. Outside work, she enjoys shopping and, on occasion, hearing about promotions and deals at her favorite shops. For this reason, she has configured webinos to accept nearby requests from sensors and networks to inform her of relevant special offers.
Gloria visits a nearby restaurant, and is alerted on her phone that the restaurant can take any information about her allergies and tailor menus specifically for her. After a few moments thought, Gloria thought this might be useful, so she agrees to share her allergy information. However, she also specifies that this information should not be shared with any other applications. On her return home, Gloria gives more thought about how the restaurants was able to alert her about allergy-specific menus. "Sometimes", Gloria thought, "I might want a little more privacy because I'm visiting somewhere more risqué or shopping for a surprise present." As she nows feels a little uncomfortable about some of her private information becoming publicly available, she decides to edit her webinos privacy preferences. In particular, she restricts the applications which might have access to her name, online identity, current location and device information. These revised preferences won't keep track of what she is doing or where she is going, and will keep her devices hidden from nearby networks. She can switch to this policy very easily, and does so whenever she feels she would like greater “nonobservability”.
task_environment.consequences:
* People have many electronic identities which they would like to keep separate, but current systems are bad at providing this isolation.
* Users do want to share data and receive personalized services. However, they need the tools to control what services are allowed to do and what data they disclose.
* Policy and privacy decisions change over time. What was once unacceptable may change, or a new application feature might persuade someone to alter their policy decisions. However, existing applications often force the decision upfront and do not make it easy for these changes to happen.
* Privacy violations can affect the trust that users have in a system or infrastructure.
* The protection of user privacy will become more important in a world dominated by sensor networks. Governments have an obligation to protect citizens and EU policies have been forward thinking in this respect. Software infrastructures should provide the necessary tools to let users make sensible decisions about their privacy.
* Privacy policies change according to domain and should be context enabled. For example -- home, venue (e.g. the café), office, street and city have different (and in some cases overlapping) privacy frameworks. In addition, specific applications will have their own privacy policies, for example in smart grids and health care.
* Policy management, no matter how well designed, can be time consuming and difficult for even technically-­skilled end users.
task_environment.benefits:
* Users are given both fine-­-grained control as well as intuitive simple control to manage their privacy and visibility.
* webinos can scale to future technologies such as sensor networks, smart grid and healthcare scenarios by managing the changing privacy and security issues.
* Users can share data with trustworthy services and applications with more confidence when policies are enforced.
* webinos can enable advertisers to tailor adverts to the right customer and offer discounts on products they have a genuine interest in. This functionality is balanced against the need for users to maintain the confidentiality of their private information and not share too much about themselves.

task.name: Privacy Controls and Analytics for Corporations an
task.author: Ajit Jaokar, John Lyle, Shamal Faily, Ivan Flechais, Hans Myrhaug, Ayse Goker
task.objective: webinos compatible analytics and privacy preferences lead to different experiences when passing a department store.\n

task_environment.name: Policy and Security
task_environment.narrative:
A central London department store wants to attract more customers by launching a retail advertising campaign taking advantage of information about the customers' mobile device to provide a more targeted and relevant campaign to individual customers. To do this, they have decided to launch the compaign which relies on ads placed within mobile web applications. If prospective customers are near a Joe Lewis store and running an application with placed advertising then, based on their preferences, they will receive a special offer entitling them to a discount on certain products. These product discounts will be tailored based on their webinos preferences. Joe Lewis will run this campaign using a large developer platform whose APIs support webinos. Support for webinos was important to Joe Lewis when selecting a platform upon which to base their advertising. Because there is a growing emphasis on consumer privacy, Joe Lewis has made the decision to only use marketing tools that conform to EU data protection regulations; they understand that their selected platform partner conforms to these regulations due to their platform APIs rely on webinos for eliciting privacy sensitive information..
Three weeks later, Peter and Gloria are walking past this store on opposite sides of the shop, and in opposite directions. Peter, who is visiting London for the weekend, receives an alert from his diary app about a special offer on sound-proof headphones, which is fortuitous as he was thinking about buying a set of these only the other day. Meanwhile, Gloria receives no messages at all because, although the platform deduced that some dietary preferences had been defined for Gloria, her policy was such that she had explicitiy asked this information not to be disclosed.
task_environment.consequences:
* webinos will provide unparalleled amounts of information about users, and provides a basis for monitoring behavior across all the device domains. This is an attractive target for advertisers and analytics companies, and webinos must expect this scenario. To make sure that privacy is maintained, webinos must provide an easy and controllable method for implementing, monitoring, and auditing functionality.
* Many free applications are driven by advertising and marketing campaigns. This is good for end users, who gain an application and new functionality, but webinos must support the business model of the developers too.
* webinos APIs co-existing with similar APIs on other platforms.
task_environment.benefits:
* Advertising, marketing and analytics are considered from a privacy perspective and webinos keeps control in the hands of the users of the devices.
* webinos caters for a wide variety of business models, including ad-driven applications and services.
* webinos can enable advertisers to tailor adverts to the right customer and offer discounts on products they have a genuine interest in. This functionality is balanced against the need for users to maintain the confidentiality of their private information and not share too much about themselves.
* webinos can be used to keep control of important data across multiple devices, despite the new threats posed by mobile and in-car systems.
